Keywords: Pool boiling Critical heat flux Nano-fluid Microstructure Particulate fouling
The present work mainly focuses on the pool boiling heat transfer of aqueous alumina nano-fluids up to critical heat flux point on a circular surface at two mass concentrations of 0.1%, 0.3% and nanoparticle size of 20 nm and 50 nm. Nano-fluids were prepared using two-step method and were stabilized by nonylphenolethoxylate (NPE), non-ionic surfactant. Surface of the heater was modified by CNC micromachinery technique and concentric circular microstructures (CCM) were created on the surface with different geometrical specifications. Results demonstrated that the heat transfer coefficient (HTC), could be deteriorated and enhanced for the plain and micro-structured surface respectively. However, rate of enhancement depended in part, to the particle size and geometrical specifications of microstructures. Rate of enhancement was found to be intensified with increasing the heat flux and mass concentration, decreasing the nanoparticles size and the interspace between microstructures, however height of microstructures had no particular influence on HTC. In terms of critical heat flux point (CHF), nanofluids expectedly enhanced the CHF value. The enhancement rate of CHF was intensified with increasing the mass concentration of nano-fluid, nano-particle size and interspace between microstructures. The main reason for enhancing the heat transfer coefficient over the micro-structured surface was due to the larger heat transfer area in comparison with plain surface. While for the plain surface, deterioration of heat transfer coefficient was due to the continual fouling formation of nanoparticles on the surface, which increased the static contact angle of nano-fluid on deposited layer and subsequently reduced the number of active nucleation sites. Capillary wicking action and constitution of inflow liquid inside the fouling layer were the main reasons for CHF enhancement since can diminish the surface dry-out regions and enhance the surface toleration against the CHF crisis. Accordingly, a modified mechanism was proposed for enhancing the CHF in nano-fluids, which was the combination of liquid absorption from the bulk of nano-fluids, by the deposition layer and inflow capillary wicking action inside the deposition layer, which leads to the rewetting phenomena in dry-out regions.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Quenching the high heat flux surfaces such as semi-conductors (e.g. micro-electronic devices (e.g. chipsets and integrated circuits)) and chemical reactors (e.g. pressurized water reactors) has been an interesting challenge for heat transfer experts. Boiling is an ideal heat transfer mechanism, which can be used in power cycles, refrigeration and cooling systems. Moreover, superior heat
transfer coefficient can be achieved in case of utilizing the boiling as a dominant cooling–heating mechanism, due to the phase change phenomena, micro/macro bubble transports and local agitations. Thus, smaller surface is required for a system working at boiling condition. Note that, boiling systems face complexities and limitations when they are utilized in industrial sector, therefore more fundamental studies are still required on the boiling mechanism and its practical applications.
Critical Heat Flux (CHF crisis), as a definition, is the limited point in which, phase change process acts in a way that bubbles can fully cover and overwhelm the heating surface and lead to the poor heat transfer. Subsequently, heat transfer coefficient decreases over the higher given heat fluxes, which can finally damage the surface or explode the heater. Generally, a nucleate

boiling system is comprised of three heat transfer mechanisms: (1) heat conduction through liquid from the boiling surface to the liquid–vapor equilibrium interface, (2) evaporation at the liquid–vapor interface towards the vapor phase (3) heat transfer by the bubbles. The critical heat flux phenomena occur, when either bubble formation or escape of vapor is restricted or hindered.
Nano-fluids [1] are promising option for the future of advanced thermal fluids due to their outstanding thermal features, especially thermal conductivity. In fact, nano-fluids represent the higher thermal conductivity rather than conventional coolants, sometimes 2–3 fold larger than that of the base fluid. Thus, many efforts have been made to investigate the potential application of nanofluid in convective systems with emphasis on the enhancement of heat transfer coefficient [2–10]. Although heat transfer enhancement was satisfactory, a small penalty for pressure drop and pumping power have been reported though. However, there is another controversial story for the nucleate boiling heat transfer. Some researchers believe that boiling heat transfer coefficient can be enhanced by nano-fluids, since nano-fluids have better thermal conductivity and convection coefficient [11–14]. The second group insists that due to the deposition of nanoparticles on the heating surface, number of nucleation sites can be reduced over the extend time and surface characteristics can be changed in a way that heat transfer coefficient is decreased over the extended time [15–18]. Interestingly, both groups have a point in common that nano-fluids can enhance the boiling CHF crisis point. For example, Ahn and his co-workers [19] performed experiments on the forced convection and CHF characteristics of nano-fluids. The experimental results showed that CHF point was distinctly enhanced at the forced convection mechanism region in comparison with pure water. Subsequent to the boiling experiments, the heater surfaces were examined with scanning electron microscope and by measuring the contact angle as well. The surface characterization results showed that CHF enhancement is mostly caused by the nanoparticles deposition on the surface during vigorous boiling of nano-fluids with a significant enhancement in wettability of surface. Kim et al. [20] conducted an experimental study on flow boiling critical heat flux (CHF) of alumina nano-fluid and alumina coated tubes. The flow boiling CHF of alumina nano-fluid with a plain tube and de-ionized water with an alumina-coated tube were enhanced up to about 80% for all experimental conditions. There was no considerable difference in the CHF results between two methods. The obtained results also indicated that the CHF enhancement of alumina nano-fluid was surely due to the deposition of nanoparticles on the inner surface of test section. Somewhere else, an experimental study was carried out by Yang and Liu [21] to investigate the pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of functionalized nano-fluid at atmospheric and sub-atmospheric
pressures. Experimental results showed that there exist great differences between pool boiling heat transfer characteristics of functionalized and traditional nano-fluid. The differences mainly resulted from the changes of surface characteristics of the heated surface during the boiling. Therefore, the pool boiling heat transfer of nano-fluids may be governed by both the thermo-properties of nano-fluids and the surface characteristics of the heated surface. In another study, Song et al. [22] experimentally investigated on boiling characteristic of SiC nano-fluid and evaluated the thermal performance of SiC nanoparticles in water pool boiling up to CHF. The volume concentrations of SiC nano-fluid were 0.0001%, 0.001% and 0.01%. The CHF values were enhanced up to 105% for volume concentration of 0.01%. CHF enhancement trend was interesting, because it did not linearly dependent on nanoparticle concentration. The wettability change of SiC nanoparticle deposited surface was discussed as main reason of CHF enhancement variation. Boiling behaviors of ZnO nano-fluid on a horizontal and vertical plate in saturated pool boiling was experimentally studied by Mourgues et al. [23] and similar findings were reported as a support of the previous literature review.
In this work, experimental study is conducted on the pool boiling heat transfer to alumina nano-fluids on a disc heater with plain and modified surfaces. To modify the surface, CNC micro-machinery was utilized and microstructures were created on the surface at different geometrical parameters. Influence of different operating parameters such as heat flux, mass concentration of nano-fluids, particle size and microstructure specifications on the pool boiling heat transfer and CHF has been experimentally investigated and deeply discussed. Surface characterizing experiments including the measurement of static contact angle, analysis of surface thermal fouling resistance and capillary wicking action were performed and their influences on the enhancement of CHF crisis point are deeply studied. Potential role of fouling thermal resistance on the heat transfer coefficient is also investigated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Experimental setup
sections.text:
Fig. 1 illustrates a schema of experimental setup used for quantifying the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient and CHF value of alumina nano-fluids. The test rig consists of four main sections:
(1) Discoid copper heater as the test section, (2) auxiliaries including pre-heater, condenser installed inside the test vessel, (3) temperature measurement instruments including thermocouples, indicators, data acquisition and a post PC processor, (4) imag-
ing system including a high-speed camera EX-F1 and a digital microscope with magnification of 500 (IP-U500x) with its specific calibration software.
In order to run the experiments, nano-fluids are loaded through the inlet port of the test vessel. The vessel is a vertical Pyrex-made cylinder, which has enough thermal resistance against thermal tension caused by main or auxiliary heaters. At the bottom of the vessel, there is a stainless steel cap, which has a perforated hole, in which the discoid copper heater is mounted. A small layer of Teflon is used to prevent from any liquid leakage and heat loss between discoid heater and the hole. This discoid heater consists of a dual diameter cylinder with an axial concentric hole at the bottom, in which a 300-W bolt heater is plugged to supply the required heat. The required power for the bolt heater is supplied by an AC transformer connected to the urban power plug. Detailed geometrical specifications of discoid heater have been presented in Fig. 2. As can be seen, the top surface of discoid heater is fixed horizontally inside the cap, so the surface can be used for pool boiling heat transfer and CHF studies. The surface is circular with outer diameter of 11 mm. In order to measure the temperature of surface, five k-type thermocouples with length of 50 mm and diameter of 1 mm (with precision of ±0.1 K) are placed inside the axial holes on the upper section of heater. By installing the thermocouples, temperature gradient can accurately be measured, which extrapolates the surface temperature of heater with a very reasonable precision. For minimizing the thermal resistance of each thermocouple, holes are filled with silicon paste. The circumference of the heater is heavily isolated by the cylindrical polytetrafluoroethylene, (PTFE) solid to prevent from any heat losses. By heavily isolating the heater, axial heat transfer towards the surface is guaranteed and no radial heat transfer can be seen in the body of the block. Moreover, potential radial heat transfer was double-checked by inserting two k-type thermocouples at (r = 0.5, r = +0.5). Results showed that temperature at this two points are the same at any given heat fluxes. So radial heat transfer can be truly ignored. For measuring the liquid bulk temperature, four RTDs (with precision of ±0.1 K) are installed at four different locations of test vessel. The arithmetic
average of RTD readings is considered as the bulk temperature of vessel. In addition, to ensure about the saturated boiling, a thermocouple is mounted at the upper part of the vessel to measure the vapor temperature. A pressure transmitter is also installed to record the pressure inside the vessel. A safety pressure valve is connected to the pressure controller to control the pressure of vessel. The system is equipped with an auxiliary heater to supply the required heat for delivering the temperature of nano-fluids to the saturation temperature. When temperature is equivalent to the saturation temperature, discoid heater is turned on for applying the required heat flux for the pool boiling experiments.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparing the nano-fluids
sections.text:
In order to prepare the nano-fluid, the method introduced in [24–26] was applied. The Al2O3 nanoparticles (20 and 50 nm, USNANO) were uniformly dispersed into the base fluid for making a stable nano-fluid (at 0.1% and 0.3% by weight). The two-step method is employed for preparing the nano-fluid. The process summarily includes the following steps:
(1) Weigh the desire mass of Al2O3 and add them into the weighted deionized water, while it was firmly agitated in a clear flask with the speed of 250 rpm and for 30 min. (2) By implementing the ultrasonic device (UP400S, 380 W/24 kHz), nano-particles were homogeneously dispersed in deionized water for 20 min to crack the agglomeration and clusters inside the bulk of nanofluids. (3) Nonylphenolethoxylate non-ionic surfactant was added into the nano-fluids (at 0.1% of general volume of nano-fluid), followed by pH control process to robust the stability of nano-fluids.
Results showed that at pH = 10.2, the most stable nano-fluid can be achieved with stability up to 35 days without any significant sedimentation. Fig. 3 shows the results of settlement-time experiments for the alumina/water nano-fluid (50 nm) at weight percentage of 0.3. In order to perform the settlement-time experiments for stabilizing the nano-fluid, the response surface methodology (RSM), was employed to optimize the stages of experiment.
In order to ensure about the morphology and quality of nanoparticle in dispersing process, quality tests were carried out. For this purpose, two samples (sample#1, 50 nm and sample#2, 20 nm) were prepared and sent to the quality test center. Results have been presented in Figs. 4–6. These tests are comprised of the PSC–DLS (particle size count by digital light scattering) test, (Transmission electron microscopy), TEM and X-ray diffraction (XRD) tests. According to the DLS (digital light scattering) test represented in Fig. 4, for two samples, mean particle size is 47–50 and 20–25 nm respectively. Fig. 5 presents the TEM images belonging to the prepared nano-fluid samples. As can be seen, neither agglomeration nor clusters inside the bulk of base fluid are seen. Moreover, nanoparticles have similar morphology.
Purity and structure of nanoparticles was also checked by XRD analysis (see Fig. 6). XRD pattern shows the single-phase Al2O3 with a monoclinic structure, which implies on this fact that there is no impurity other than Al2O3 nanoparticles, because no significant peaks of impurities can be found in XRD pattern. The peaks are also broad due to the nano-size effect.

sections.heading: 2.3. Surface specifications
sections.text: The boiling surface is a flat disc fabricated from copper, which has been modified using CNC micro-machinery technique to have microstructures with concentric circular shape. Fig. 7 depicts the microscopic images taken from the surface showing the geometrical specifications of microstructures. In order to investigate the impact of geometrical specifications of microstructures on the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of nano-fluid, different surfaces with various geometrical specifications were provided, which have been given in Table 1. The geometrical parameters are width (W), (values of 150 and 500 lm); height (H), (values of 50 and 100 lm) and wall interspace between microstructures (S), (values of 50 and 500 lm).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text: For evaluating the thermal performance of alumina aqueous nano-fluids, heat transfer coefficient is conveniently implemented as a merit criterion. Due to the deposition of nano-fluid over the extended time, studies are transiently conducted (considering the running time of experiments). Following sections represent the obtained results and related discussions.

sections.heading: 3.1. Pool boiling heat transfer of DI-water
3.1.1. Heat transfer coefficient
sections.text:
Before establishing the experiments on the pool boiling of nanofluids, preliminary tests and calibrating process were performed on pure water and results were compared to well-known predicting correlations. In order to check the integrity of results, experimental data for DI-water were compared to Cornwell–Houston correlation [28], modified Gorenflo and Rohsenow correlations [29] (for heat transfer coefficient close to CHF) and Zuber [30] (for CHF crisis point). As shown in Fig. 10, this comparison indicates that results are in a good agreement with available correlations. For better understanding, the absolute average deviation, (AAD3) values have been represented in Fig. 11. This validation shows that experimental data obtained for alumina nano-fluids can be reliable.
Cornwell–Houston correlation can predict the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of deionized water with higher in comparison with other correlations. For other ones, it can be stated that experimental data have been under-predicted and over-predicted by Rohsenow and Gorenflo correlations respectively. Noticeably, Rohsenow and Gorenflo correlations strongly depend on the thermo-physical properties of fluid, therefore the internal tuning parameters in these correlations, should carefully be adjusted to have enough accuracy. Since properties of DI water are well known and available in the handbooks, therefore, these correlations can be considered as the suitable reference. Zuber correlation also predicts the CHF value with a reasonable accuracy in comparison with our work (1100 vs. 1170 kW/m2). As expected, experimental results demonstrated that the pool boiling heat transfer of water is highly dependent to the applied heat flux such that by increasing the heat flux, heat transfer coefficient significantly increases. This phenomenon is in a good agreement with the results published in the literature [13–17]. In fact, intensification of bubble formation phenomenon is the major reason for enhancing the heat transfer coefficient at higher heat fluxes. At lower heat fluxes, heat transfer coefficient is considerably lower than moderate and high heat flux regions. Because, rate of bubble formation is relatively poor in comparison with moderate and higher heat flux regions, while at moderate heat fluxes, bigger bubbles gradually appear on the surface and transfer the heat from the surface towards the bulk of fluid. When higher heat flux is applied, rates of bubbles departing the heater significantly improve, which result in local agitation of boiling micro-layer around the surface [24]. In this condition, heat transfer coefficient can be increased s well. This trend can be seen for the plain and micro-structured surfaces.

Fig. 12 presents the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of deionized water on plain and micro-structured surfaces.
According to the results demonstrated in Fig. 12, space between circular microstructures seems to be an important, because for CCMs with lower space, higher heat transfer coefficient was obtained, while height of CCM had slightly negative impact on the heat transfer coefficient that can be ignored. In terms of width of CCMs, results demonstrated that microstructures with lower width have better boiling performance. Briefly speaking, CCM#1 had better thermal performance due to its lower interspace and width values. The obtained results are in a good agreement with studies conducted by Webb et al. [31] and Pastuszko [32]. According to the definition of critical heat flux, this phenomenon happens, when heat cannot be transferred from the surface. Therefore, accumulation of heat on the surface leads the surface temperature to be higher than the allowable temperature. Accordingly, surface can be damaged. This condition can particularly be seen, when coolant is evaporated around the surface. For pure water, it seems that microstructures with larger space, width and height are suitable for enhancing the CHF. Because, more liquid can be available on the boiling surface, while for small microstructures, space between microstructure walls (micro-channels) can be vapor-filled due to the evaporation of liquid. As a result, due to the poor thermal conductivity of vapor, heat cannot properly be transferred. Therefore, heat is accumulated and CHF can be intensified. However, this explanation is only acceptable for the pure liquids. When it comes to the nano-fluids, conditions will be different. Study on the pool
boiling of nano-fluids on microstructures surface have been discussed in Section 3.2.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Bubble formation
sections.text:
Fig. 13 shows the bubble formation of DI water on the plain surface at different applied heat fluxes near the CHF point. As can be seen, rate of bubble formation is considerably dependent to the heat flux. At low and moderate heat fluxes, bubbles are discreetly formed on the surface. Moreover, the number of active nucleation sites is increased by increasing the heat flux. At relatively higher heat fluxes (>600 kW/m2), bubble coalescence is strongly intensified, since number of nucleation sites are extensive at high heat flux region. For instance, at heat fluxes equivalent to 90–95% of CHF, a mushroom-shaped vapor blanket is constituted on the surface, which significantly deteriorates the heat transfer rate and causes the critical heat flux crisis. The observations are in a good agreement with those of reported by Haramura and Katto [33]. This mushroom shaped vapor blanket is formed due to the intensification of bubble coalescence phenomenon.
At higher heat fluxes, especially at CHF point, bubbles depart the surface in a form of uniform vapor blanket with a mushroom shape. Such vapor blanket can create a hotspot region underneath the coalesced bubbles. These regions are vapor-filled and can enhance the possibility of CHF crisis. Formation of vapor blanket (coalesced bubbles) can fully cover the heating surface and as the result, leads to the hotspot and dry-out phenomena, which leads to the heater failure [34]. Such vapor blankets remain longer on the surface and subsequently, large quantity of heat cannot be
transferred to the bulk of fluid due the poor thermal conductivity of vapor. This can considerably decrease the heat transfer coefficient. For better understanding, Fig. 14 presents the rate of bubble detachment from the disk heater for DI-water at two different heat fluxes.
As can be seen in Fig. 14, bubbles spend more time on the surface before detaching (approximately 18 ms for HF = 910 vs. 9 ms for HF = 220), which can enhance the possibility of CHF crisis at high heat flux condition. In case of using microstructures, experiments show that CHF can slightly be enhanced, since microstructures (regardless of wall interspace) can create a limitation in bubble size and vapor blanket size. Therefore, more heat transfer area remains available. This can delay the CHF crisis. Table 3 shows the measured critical heat flux for different boiling surface. Noticeably, surface modified with microstructures with narrow walls has almost less impact on CHF point. It can be due to the limited space between walls that can hold small quantity of liquid. Subsequently, this liquid can be quickly evaporated and subsequently, microchannels between structures are vapor-filled. In this condition, due to the poor thermal conductivity of vapor, heat cannot be transferred from the surface, which leads to the CHF crisis. Therefore, smaller microstructures are not suitable for enhancing the CHF crisis point, although they can slightly increase the CHF point. However, these microstructures have better thermal performance for convective and nucleate boiling heat transfer, since they have higher specific heat transfer area like the extended surface. Noticeably, results belonging to HTC are in a good agreement with those of represented by [33,34].

sections.heading: 3.2. Pool boiling heat transfer of nano-fluids
sections.text:
Fig. 15(a and b) present the heat transfer coefficient of nanofluids at different concentrations on a plain surface after 1000 min of operation. Since deposition is the major challenge of using nano-fluid in boiling media, therefore, transient experiments must be conducted. As can be seen, for all nano-fluids, regardless of concentration and nano-particles size, pool boiling heat transfer coefficient is deteriorated over the extended time. During this time, nano-particles start forming the scales and aggregations despite of the fact that, they have been stabilized using pre-treatments such as pH control and ultrasonic. Note that, close to the heating surface,
a boiling micro/macro layer is depleted from the base fluid and a concentrated bulk of nano-fluid is constituted around the surface. In this condition, nanoparticles stick to the neighbor particles and form aggregation. Moreover, such deposition can change the wettability and bubble nucleation sites, which can deteriorate or enhance the bubble transport mechanism depending on the size of irregularities and microstructures on the surface.
For nano-particles with smaller size, higher pool boiling heat transfer coefficient is reported. There are three possible reasons for this fact as follows: The first reason is that: the smaller nanoparticles have higher thermal conduction due to their specific surface area, which facilitate the heat transfer from surface towards the bulk of fluid. Second reason can be related to this fact that: smaller particles can compensate the suppression of heat transfer due to the bubble isolation phenomenon at high heat flux region, since they have better Brownian motion and local mobility inside the bulk of base fluid. These particles are stimulated by bubble interactions and micro-streams, so they can transfer the heat from the surface towards the bulk of fluid. The third reason is the kinetic effect and fouling morphology of nanoparticles in fouling layer. Although smaller nanoparticles can fill the surface cavities and the irregularities and possibly reduce the number of nucleation sites, they form a thin nano-particle layer with more irregularities and less thermal resistance on the heating surface in comparison with larger nano-particles. Thanks to the bubble formation, deposited nanoparticles can be detached from the surface. Therefore, irregularity and morphology of fouling layer is constantly changed
eater surface, (a) alumina nano-fluid 20 nm and (b) alumina nano-fluid 50 nm.
during boiling and subsequently, nucleation sites continuously change on the surface. Detaching the smaller particle is easier than larger ones. In this work, for the plain surface, any nano-particles regardless of its size deteriorated the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient, while for smaller nano-particles rate of deterioration was lower than that of obtained for the larger nano-particles.
According to the experimental data represented in Fig. 15(a and b), rate of deterioration of heat transfer coefficient on the plain surface can be intensified with increasing the mass concentration of nano-fluid and increasing the nano-particle size, while for applied heat flux, as expected, heat transfer coefficient increases.
Boiling experiments on the modified surfaces demonstrated that regardless of geometrical differences between the surfaces and at any nanoparticle sizes, the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient was enhanced. However, rate of enhancement was different and depended on the geometrical properties. Fig. 16 represents the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient measured on microstructured surfaces. According to the results, for CCM#1, the highest boiling thermal performance can be seen.
Since more heat transfer area is available for CCM#1, higher heat transfer coefficient can be obtained. On the other hand, the fouling layer formed on the CCM#1 has more irregularities, which create more nucleation active sites. Thus, stronger bubble
formation can be seen on the CCM#1 surface (see Figs. 23a and 23b). Consequently, lower thermal fouling resistance can also be seen for this microstructure. Note that, micro-structured surfaces have different behavior in fouling formation, which has deeply been investigated in Section 3.2.2. In terms of CHF, pool boiling of nano-fluids demonstrated that CHF on plain and microstructured surfaces could be enhanced. The reason for this fact was due to the capillary wicking of deposition layer, static contact angle of surface and thermal fouling resistance, which have been discussed in following sections.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Capillary wicking of deposition layer
sections.text:
Fig. 17 demonstrates the mechanism of enhancement of CHF in pool boiling of alumina nano-fluid, which is the combination of mushroom and micro/macro boiling layer mechanisms and assumptions. This modified mechanism can truly explain the reason for the CHF enhancement in alumina nano-fluids and is consistent with the literature. As mentioned, in pool boiling of non-particulate liquids, when a bubble forms on a boiling surface, a hotspot region (the area that liquid is totally evaporated) is formed on the surface. Such regions can cause damages to the surface, since this region is vapor-filled and thermal conductivity of vapor is significantly lower than liquid, as a result, heat cannot be transferred to the bulk of liquid properly. When boiling phenomena come to the nano-fluids, due to the deposition of nanoparticles on the surface, a porous layer may be formed on the surface. Such layer can create a capillary wicking action on the surface such that: (1) Liquid is absorbed by the porous layer from the bulk of liquid. (2) The absorbed liquid is derived to the hotspot region underneath the bubbles by internal capillary wicking action of porous layer. By occurring these phenomena, more liquids can remain inside the porous layer, which delays the CHF crisis. In fact, the induced capillary wicking action causes the re-wetting phenomenon underneath the growing bubbles. This mechanism agrees well with those of previously proposed by Liu et al. [35], Yang et al. [36] and Kim et al. [37]. In the literature, according to the results reported by Kim et al. [38–40], there were some model such as Kandlikar model, which seems inadequate to fully explain the CHF enhancement of nano-fluids [41,42].
Noticeably, in order to ensure about the surface porosity, scanning electron microscope, SEM was implemented. The SEM images were provided from the surface before and after boiling experiments to show the porosity and capillary wicking capability. Images have been presented in Fig. 18.

Fig. 19 comparatively demonstrates the thermal performance of micro-structured and plain surfaces. For a meaningful comparison, the heat transfer coefficient is regarded as a criterion for thermal performance and comparison is made at mass concentration of 0.3, applied heat flux of 550 kW/m2 and for both nano-particle sizes. As can be seen in Fig. 18, plain surface decreased the heat transfer coefficient, regardless the size of nano-fluids. However, for modified surface, at any operating conditions and geometrical specifications, the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient is enhanced.
In terms of nanoparticle size, rate of heat transfer enhancement on the micro-structured surfaces was lower, when larger nanoparticles (50 nm) were implemented in nano-fluids, which is due to the kinetic effect and morphology of larger nanoparticles that can have influence on the rate of deposition and fouling formation on the surface. In addition, as mentioned larger particles have smaller specific area. Therefore, study on fouling formation seems to be necessary and should be carefully considered, which has been discussed in following section.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Surface fouling resistance
sections.text:
In order to investigate the role of particle size on the particulate fouling of nano-fluids, fouling thermal resistance parameter is used, which is defined as:
Rf ¼ 1hf 1 hc
ð8Þ
In Eq. (8), Rf is the fouling resistance parameter, which is the merit criterion for demonstrating the role of fouling. hf is the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient when fouling is formed on the surface and hc is the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of a clean surface. Noticeably, fouling resistance parameter can be obtained at
Fig. 20a demonstrates the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient and fouling resistance parameter for the alumina nano-fluids at different particle sizes for weight percentage = 0.1 on the plain surface. As can be seen, heat transfer coefficient gradually decreases over the extended time. In fact, deposition of nanoparticles can create a significant fouling resistance on the surface, which causes the boiling heat transfer coefficient to be decreased over the extended time. Note that, the fouling layer is porous; therefore, higher thermal resistance can be expected. According to Fig. 20b, fouling resistance trend has non-linear increasing behavior with time, which is
in a good agreement with previous studies [26,43–45]. For other nano-fluids, similar behavior was registered on the plain surface such that with increasing the mass concentration of nano-fluid, fouling resistance considerably increases, which causes a decreasing trend in heat transfer coefficient.
There are also some fluctuations in Fig. 19b, which is due to the bubble interactions and detachment/attachment of nano-particles on the surface.
In previous section, our results indicated that micro-structured surface of CCM#1 had the best thermal performance amongst the other surfaces. Therefore, extra experiments were performed on the fouling formation of nano-particles on CCM#1 surface as a case study.
Fig. 21 shows the influence of concentration of nano-fluids on the fouling resistance parameter for CCM#1 surface. As can be seen, with increasing the mass concentration of nano-fluids, fouling resistance is slightly changed over the extended time.
The reason can be related to this fact that for CCM#1, more nanoparticles can fill the interspace between microstructures and subsequently, no aggregations can be formed. As a result, thickness of fouling does not increase over the time. Moreover, walls of microstructures prevent from formation of continual fouling layer and create massive irregular fouling and scales on the surface, which leads to the very slight change in number of nucleation sites. Actually, these irregularities can potentially be further nucleation sites. Subsequently, fouling resistance parameter gradually increases. In terms of nano-particle size, results revealed that for alumina nano-fluid with 50 nm particle size, average fouling resistance was found to be 38% higher in comparison with those of measured for alumina with 20 nm particles. In order to determine the fouling thickness of nano-particles on the surface, a profile meter was employed (manufactured by Elcometer) and results were compared to the well-known existing correlation for estimating the fouling thickness:
Rf ¼ dfkp ð9Þ
In Eq. (9), d is the fouling thickness (lm) and kp is thermal conductivity of nano-particles, however, it is assumed that, fouling thickness is uniformly formed on the surface (non-porous layer) and the conduction heat transfer is the dominant mechanism in deposited layer. To the best of our knowledge, this traditional equation may be far from the practical application, since the assumptions are far from practical situation [46]. Therefore, a comparison was performed between those of measured by thickness-gauge profile meter and those of obtained from Eq. (9). Fig. 22 shows the fouling
thickness of nano-particles for different nano-particle size. As expected, by increasing the operating time, thickness of fouling increases. Moreover, increase in mass concentration of nano-fluid can enhance the fouling thickness too. Likewise, theoretical results obtained by Eq. (9) demonstrated a good agreement, when comparing to the experimental results within the deviation of ±42.7%.
Note that, due to the morphology of nano-particles, porosity of deposited layer strictly varies location to location over the surface. Therefore, estimating the thermal conductivity coefficient of fouling layer is very difficult [46].
As an evidence, in Figs. 23a and 23b, fouling formation of alumina nano-fluids on plain and micro-structured surfaces have been presented. As can be seen, fouling layer is discretely formed on the micro-structured surface, while fouling layer on the plain surface is continual.
As can also be seen in Fig. 23b, fouling is not uniformly formed on the surface. Somewhere, thickness of fouling is relatively lower than other locations. Therefore, in comparison with a plain surface, more heat transfer area is still available and lower thermal resistance due to the fouling is reported for micro-structured surfaces.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Static contact angle
sections.text:
Since deposition of nanoparticles can change the surface wettability, therefore, studying the capillary wicking and fouling resistance are not enough for explaining the enhancement/ deterioration of heat transfer coefficient and CHF as well. Thus, visual observations were also performed on the static contact angle of liquid drop on the surface before and after boiling experiments. According to Eq. (10), contact angle has a strong influence on capillary wicking [36]:
Lc ¼ 2r cos hRcqg ð10Þ
In Eq. (10), r is surface tension, Lc is capillary and h is contact angle. The best CHF value can be found, when the contact angle approaches to zero. In order to measure the static contact angle, a drop of nano-fluid (with approximate volume of 1 ll) is placed on the boiling surface in presence of a ballast non-flicker light. Image is taken by a horizontal digital microscope IUP500 . Then the contact angle is visually measured using the measurement software (cooling tech with accuracy of 1%). Figs. 24a and 24b demonstrate the static contact angle of liquid drop on deposited and nondeposited micro-structured surfaces. According to the results, deposition layer of nano-particles can decrease the static contact angle. In addition, with increasing the rate of deposition due to the mass
concentration of nanoparticles, static contact angle considerably decreases.
Based on Fig. 24a, liquid drop can have higher contact angle on the surface with smaller microstructures such that for CCM#1 liquid drop has contact angle equivalent to 87.9, while this value decreases for CCM#6 and CCM#8 to 79.9 and 53.8 respectively. Therefore, another reason for enhancing the heat transfer coefficient on micro-structured surface is contact angle. On smaller microstructures, more nucleation sites are available since liquid drops do not lie on the surface and nucleation cavities are not filled with liquid. While for CHF, on larger microstructures, contact angle is smaller. Therefore, wettability of surface considerably increases and capillary wicking is intensified, which is in accordance with Eq. (9). Moreover, according to Fig. 24b, it can also be stated that with increasing the concentration of nano-fluid, static contact angle decreases, meaning that wettability of surface regardless of type of surface (micro-structured or plain) is enhanced. In this condition, more nucleation sites on the surface can be filled with liquid and subsequently, activity of nucleation sites decreases Therefore, bubble formation is suppressed on surfaces with higher wettability. Results of this work showed that available heat transfer area is the most effective parameter for enhancing the heat transfer coefficient, while static contact angle and fouling formation are key parameters in CHF enhancement. Micro-structured surface can provide more heat transfer area, lower fouling resistance, and higher contact angles. Therefore, boiling heat transfer coefficient can be enhanced on micro-structured surfaces. In addition, CHF enhancement is another advantage of micro-structured surfaces.

sections.heading: 4. Concluding remarks
sections.text:
Experimental investigations on the pool boiling thermal performance of alumina nano-fluid on the plain and micro-structured surfaces were performed. A modified mechanism was proposed for the enhancement of critical heat flux point. Based on the proposed model, the main reason for enhancing the CHF point was the absorption of base fluid by the deposition porous layer and the induced capillary wicking action inside the deposited layer, which can return the liquid to the dry-out regions beneath the bubbles. By re-wetting the dry-out regions, CHF occurs with the significant delay. For the plain surface nanoparticles formed a uniformly continual layer of deposition on the surface, which decreased the number of active nucleation sites and rate of bubble formation. However, for micro-structured surface, an irregular deposition was constituted due to the walls of microstructures, which created more active nucleation sites and rigorous bubble formation. Likewise, deposition was found to change the surface characteristics; such that particle deposition caused the contact angle of liquid drop on the boiling surface to be decreased.
Subsequently, wettability of surface increased and led to the capillary wicking action to be enhanced. Besides, it was found that smaller microstructures are not suitable for enhancing the CHF, while such structures can be used for enhancing the heat transfer coefficient. Overall, a micro-structured boiling surface not only are the promising passive way, but also a cost-effective method to enhance the pool boiling heat transfer coefficient in nanofluids. Moreover, by combining the application of nano-fluids and micro-structured surface may provide the superior heat transfer rate and significant CHF enhancement.
